title: Advanced Targeted Learning Methods
text:
Code
library(lmtp)
set.seed(123)
data(example_data)
fit <- lmtp_tmle(example_data, trt = "A", outcome = "Y",
                 baseline = c("L1","L2"),
                 shift = function(data, trt) data[[trt]] + 0.5,
                 folds = 2)
summary(fit)

title: Workshop: The Causal Roadmap and TMLE in Pharmacoepidemiology
text:
This workshop introduces the Causal Roadmap and Targeted Maximum Likelihood Estimation (TMLE) through a motivating example: a post-market evaluation of cardiovascular safety among patients treated with denosumab (Prolia) vs. zoledronic acid for osteoporosis. The goal is to show how causal inference frameworks help produce transparent, reproducible real-world evidence.
In 2023, Amgen conducted a large-scale retrospective cohort study across two US claims databases, comparing denosumab with zoledronic acid. After adjusting for confounding using inverse probability weighting, the study found no increased risk of myocardial infarction or stroke up to 36 months of follow-up【204†source】. Here, we will reconstruct a simplified version of this question using the causal roadmap and a TMLE implementation.






Note



Goal: Learn how to define, identify, and estimate a causal effect with TMLE, using machine learning for nuisance function estimation.


 Figure 1. The Causal Roadmap, adapted for pharmacoepidemiologic safety analysis.

title: Introductory Workshop: The Causal Roadmap and TMLE
text:
Code
library(tmle)


Loading required package: glmnet


Loading required package: Matrix


Loaded glmnet 4.1-8


Loading required package: SuperLearner


Loading required package: nnls

Loading required package: splines

Super Learner


Version: 2.0-29


Package created on 2024-02-06


Welcome to the tmle package, version 2.0.1.1

Use tmleNews() to see details on changes and bug fixes


Code
set.seed(1234)
n <- 500
W <- data.frame(age = rnorm(n, 60, 10), sex = rbinom(n, 1, 0.5))
A <- rbinom(n, 1, plogis(-1 + 0.02*W$age + 0.5*W$sex))
Y <- rbinom(n, 1, plogis(-2 + 1*A + 0.03*W$age))
res <- tmle(Y = Y, A = A, W = W, family = "binomial")

title: Causal roadmap tutorial applied to the case study of an AKI safety signal
text:
Welcome to the Causal Roadmap Tutorial.
This section walks through three major steps of the causal inference roadmap using an acute kidney injury (AKI) case study comparing sofosbuvir-containing vs non-sofosbuvir antiviral regimens.
Each chapter corresponds to a key step of the causal roadmap:

Step 1a – Causal Question and Causal Estimand
Defining the causal question and selecting the estimand under the ICH E9(R1) framework.
Steps 1b–2 – Causal Model and Observed Data
Building the causal model, DAG, and mapping variables from the data-generating process.
Step 3 – Identification and Causal Assumptions
Linking the causal estimand to the observed data through identification assumptions.




These materials are designed to teach the first steps of the Causal Roadmap in a regulatory-grade RWE analysis.
The content aligns with the ICH E9(R1) estimand framework and follows a target trial emulation approach.
By the end of this section, you will be able to:

Define a causal question that aligns with clinical intent.

Identify estimands suitable for post-market safety evaluation.

Understand how causal assumptions translate into statistical estimators.

title: Targeted Learning for Real-World Evidence
text:
Welcome!
This site introduces the Causal Roadmap, Targeted Maximum Likelihood Estimation (TMLE), and Super Learner for modern causal inference in epidemiology, with an emphasis on pharmacoepidemiology and clinical trial analysis.


Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.4.3

title: Workshop: The Causal Roadmap and TMLE in Pharmacoepidemiology
text:
4.1 Why TMLE?
As described by Katherine Hoffman in An Illustrated Guide to TMLE【202†source】【203†source】, TMLE: - Targets a specific estimand (e.g., ATE), rather than model coefficients. - Incorporates data-adaptive methods like Super Learner. - Provides valid standard errors and confidence intervals.

title: Workshop: The Causal Roadmap and TMLE in Pharmacoepidemiology
text:
4.2 Why Super Learner?
Super Learner (SL) combines multiple algorithms (GLM, LASSO, random forests, etc.) through cross-validation to minimize prediction error. This ensemble approach ensures flexibility and robustness when estimating nuisance parameters.


Code
library(SuperLearner)


Loading required package: nnls


Loading required package: gam


Loading required package: splines


Loading required package: foreach


Loaded gam 1.22-5


Super Learner


Version: 2.0-29


Package created on 2024-02-06


Code
set.seed(123)
sl_libs <- c('SL.glm', 'SL.glmnet', 'SL.ranger', 'SL.earth')

title: 3. TMLE Concepts and Implementation
text:
Why TMLE?
TMLE provides a robust, efficient estimator for causal effects combining outcome regression and propensity score modeling.
It is doubly robust and allows the use of machine learning while preserving valid inference.


Code
library(tmle)


Loading required package: glmnet


Loading required package: Matrix


Loaded glmnet 4.1-8


Loading required package: SuperLearner


Loading required package: nnls


Loading required package: gam


Loading required package: splines


Loading required package: foreach


Loaded gam 1.22-5


Super Learner


Version: 2.0-29


Package created on 2024-02-06


Welcome to the tmle package, version 2.0.1.1

Use tmleNews() to see details on changes and bug fixes


Code
library(SuperLearner)
set.seed(123)
fit <- tmle(Y, A, W, family = "binomial",
            Q.SL.library = c("SL.glm", "SL.glmnet", "SL.ranger"),
            g.SL.library = c("SL.glm", "SL.ranger"))


Loading required namespace: ranger


Code
summary(fit)

title: 4. SuperLearner and Ensemble Methods
text:
The Idea Behind Super Learner
Super Learner combines multiple models into one optimal prediction algorithm using cross-validation.


Code
library(SuperLearner)


Loading required package: nnls


Loading required package: gam


Loading required package: splines


Loading required package: foreach


Loaded gam 1.22-5


Super Learner


Version: 2.0-29


Package created on 2024-02-06


Code
set.seed(123)
#sl_lib <- c("SL.glm", "SL.mean", "SL.glmnet", "SL.randomForest")
sl_lib <- c("SL.glm") #simpler library for speed
SL_fit <- SuperLearner(Y, X = W, newX = W, family = binomial(), SL.library = sl_lib)
summary(SL_fit)


                  Length Class  Mode       
call                 6   -none- call       
libraryNames         1   -none- character  
SL.library           2   -none- list       
SL.predict        1000   -none- numeric

library.predict   1000   -none- numeric    
Z                 1000   -none- numeric    
cvRisk               1   -none- numeric

title: 5. Putting It All Together
text:
Integrating the Steps
In this final section, we bring together all steps of the Causal Roadmap and Targeted Learning pipeline.

# Full workflow

title: Causal roadmap tutorial applied to the case study of an AKI safety signal
text:
These materials are designed to teach the first steps of the Causal Roadmap in a regulatory-grade RWE analysis.
The content aligns with the ICH E9(R1) estimand framework and follows a target trial emulation approach.
By the end of this section, you will be able to:

Define a causal question that aligns with clinical intent.

Identify estimands suitable for post-market safety evaluation.

Understand how causal assumptions translate into statistical estimators.

title: Steps 1b–2 – Causal Model and Observed Data
text:
The causal model specifies assumptions and relationships among variables needed for valid inference.


We emulate a two‑arm pragmatic trial:

A=1: Sofosbuvir‑containing regimen

A=0: Non‑sofosbuvir regimen

Follow‑up: 90 days for first AKI or censoring




W ─▶ A ─▶ Y
│     │
└────▶ Y

W: Baseline confounders (age, CKD, cirrhosis, HIV)
A: Treatment assignment
Y: AKI outcome within 90 days




Exchangeability: No unmeasured confounding given W

Positivity: All W values have non‑zero probability of receiving each treatment

Consistency: Each individual’s outcome under observed A equals counterfactual Yᵃ

title: Steps 1b–2 – Causal Model and Observed Data
text:
We emulate a two‑arm pragmatic trial:

A=1: Sofosbuvir‑containing regimen

A=0: Non‑sofosbuvir regimen

│     │
└────▶ Y

A: Treatment assignment
Y: AKI outcome within 90 days




Exchangeability: No unmeasured confounding given W

Positivity: All W values have non‑zero probability of receiving each treatment

Consistency: Each individual’s outcome under observed A equals counterfactual Yᵃ

title: Steps 1b–2 – Causal Model and Observed Data
text:
Observed Data Vector
[ O = (W, A, T, ) ]



Variable
Description




W
Baseline covariates (demographics, comorbidities)


A
Binary treatment: SOF=1, non‑SOF=0


T
Follow‑up time to AKI or censoring


Δ
Indicator: 1=AKI, 0=censored




Censoring Rules



Dataset
Purpose
Censoring




Primary
Hypothetical no‑switch
AKI, administrative, or switch


Sensitivity
Treatment‑policy (ITT)
AKI or admin only



These data definitions ensure reproducibility and map directly to the causal model.
